commit_message:
Propagate cloud_provider_enabled correctly

The derived cloud_provider_enabled is placed inside extra_params so that
openstack-cloud-controller-manager gets applied correctly. This required
change was unfortulately missed in https://review.opendev.org/681922.

Additionally improve  the docs related to cloud_provider_enabled label.

Story: 2006531
Task: 36740

Change-Id: I4a89d25b467edd2c4be608c37055706e4e62d78b
(cherry picked from commit 459e27e688d4cd9209060c277e17823c698ee5ac)

I noticed jenkins failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- gate-magnum-docs-ubuntu-xenial: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1617309 https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1298006

commit_message:
[opensuse] Move opensuse driver to main tree

This patch includes the changes needed to align the opensuse
driver to the other drivers in the magnum/drivers and removes the
driver from contrib/drivers.

Implements: blueprint k8s-opensuse-support
Change-Id: Id228b6d68d873eb2a45503ccd66b5c465ee16c70

fix for those wrong links.

commit_message:
Check the size of instance name before creating certificate

When the size of instance name is greater then 52, send 'FAILURE'
to heat.

Change-Id: Ica22c12e7cf4191ba4012947bac087a03f8b6ca4

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-08 02:43:14.000000000', 'message': "Don't use hostname on subjectAltName

The kubelet kubeconfig use instance name, not hostname which
contains '.novalocal'. So the cert file just need instance name.
BTW, if the size of instance name is 63, the cert file can't use
hostname. The size of subjectAltName must '< 64'.

Change-Id: I7eb7078cc9ad3f0e026b5cb2019904904d5f64b8
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use hostname on subjectAltName

The kubelet kubeconfig use instance name, not hostname which
contains '.novalocal'. So the cert file just need instance name.
BTW, if the size of instance name is 63, the cert file can't use
hostname. The size of subjectAltName must '< 64'.

Change-Id: I7eb7078cc9ad3f0e026b5cb2019904904d5f64b8

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20031, 'date': '2017-06-26 11:53:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

you should NOT need a specific image. Since we don't use the heat agent in this driver (user_data_format: RAW) it should work without any image modification. However you need the cloud-init metadatas to work. For that on a Ironic setup you either need to NAT the magic IP 169.254.169.254 to the actual metadata server IP, or use a drive for the cloud-init config. You don't see the problem with VM since the metadata server IP is NAT directly in the host compute node through an iptables rule."}, {'account_id': 20031, 'date': '2017-06-26 12:09:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You should be able to test if your cloud-init ironic setup is working just by ssh into the machine using the key specified in nova boot.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2017-06-26 12:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> you should NOT need a specific image. Since we don't use the heat
 > agent in this driver (user_data_format: RAW) it should work without
 > any image modification. However you need the cloud-init metadatas
 > to work. For that on a Ironic setup you either need to NAT the
 > magic IP 169.254.169.254 to the actual metadata server IP, or use a
 > drive for the cloud-init config. You don't see the problem with VM
 > since the metadata server IP is NAT directly in the host compute
 > node through an iptables rule.

There may be cases where a standard VM image can be used for baremetal, but my environment is not one. I need the following elements:

- dhcp-all-interfaces: Our compute nodes have multiple interfaces. In general we require this element to ensure we begin DHCP discovery on the correct interface. Admittedly I haven't verified that this is the case with fedora-atomic.
- dracut-regenerate (or dracut-network): Our nodes have RAID hardware that is not supported by the standard fedora cloud image. We use this element to rebuild the ramdisk.
- enable-serial-console: This is useful for debugging.

Also, in order to use an ephemeral partition for docker storage, it is necessary to use the 'baremetal' element instead of the 'vm' element. This creates an unpartitioned disk image and extracts the kernel and ramdisk. As it stands however, the k8s VM driver cannot be made to use an ephemeral disk partition, so devicemapper storage will not work.

Here's the instructions to build the baremetal image for k8s for reference: https://github.com/openstack/magnum/tree/master/magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_ironic_v1/image/kubernetes"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2017-06-26 12:56:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> you should NOT need a specific image. Since we don't use the heat
 > agent in this driver (user_data_format: RAW) it should work without
 > any image modification. However you need the cloud-init metadatas
 > to work. For that on a Ironic setup you either need to NAT the
 > magic IP 169.254.169.254 to the actual metadata server IP, or use a
 > drive for the cloud-init config. You don't see the problem with VM
 > since the metadata server IP is NAT directly in the host compute
 > node through an iptables rule.

Oh, and on the cloud-init front - neutron provides a route to the metadata server via DHCP, so I get the following:

$ ip r
<snip>
169.254.169.254 via 10.60.253.10 dev eno1  proto static"}, {'account_id': 20031, 'date': '2017-06-26 13:06:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Great thanks for the details, we are at the beginning of Ironic here.
We don't have your hardware problems for now and are using specific IPMI software to access the TTY.
Good to know for the routing ! I completely forgot that you could give routes through DHCP, I'll see if we have enough control on the network to do that.
So on the driver side we should only miss some ifs around LVM config and handling of ephemeral storage right ?"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2017-06-26 13:26:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Great thanks for the details, we are at the beginning of Ironic
 > here.
 > We don't have your hardware problems for now and are using specific
 > IPMI software to access the TTY.
 > Good to know for the routing ! I completely forgot that you could
 > give routes through DHCP, I'll see if we have enough control on the
 > network to do that.
 > So on the driver side we should only miss some ifs around LVM
 > config and handling of ephemeral storage right ?

No problem. Yes, I think it's quite close. The current logic[1] in the BM k8s driver says:

When docker_storage_size is not None and cinder is disabled, assume there is an ephemeral disk partition (with label ephemeral0), use it for docker storage.

When using devicemapper, an LVM VG is created on this partition. When using overlay, the partition is formatted with an XFS file system and this is mounted at /var/lib/docker. Ideally both of these use cases would continue to work.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/magnum/blob/master/magnum/drivers/common/templates/fragments/configure-docker-storage.sh#L10"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2017-06-26 13:27:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Great thanks for the details, we are at the beginning of Ironic
 > here.
 > We don't have your hardware problems for now and are using specific
 > IPMI software to access the TTY.
 > Good to know for the routing ! I completely forgot that you could
 > give routes through DHCP, I'll see if we have enough control on the
 > network to do that.
 > So on the driver side we should only miss some ifs around LVM
 > config and handling of ephemeral storage right ?

Oh, and on the routing - we don't do anything special for that to happen, it's all done by neutron automatically."}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2017-07-06 08:46:41.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from I9bc0b074ece429bb2283d3e7f3a3948a75b80f3c to magnum-fix-ironic'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2017-07-13 09:44:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more

    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 05:39:58.000000000', 'message': '    remove etcd.service dependency for flannel-config.service

    if not remove etcd dependency for flannel-config, when etcd is not ready(but etcd will start success finally),
    the flannel-config service will excute failed,and not restart again

    acutually,/usr/local/bin/flannel-config will  write flannel config when etcd become ready,use

    while ! curl -sf -L $ETCD_CURL_OPTIONS \
            $FLANNEL_ETCD_ENDPOINTS/v2/keys${FLANNEL_ETCD_PREFIX}/config \
            -X PUT --data-urlencode value@${FLANNEL_JSON}; do
        echo "waiting for etcd"
        sleep 1
    done

    so let's remove this dependency

Change-Id: I5eb3faa6af89ade0301486470318193830e109cd

commit_message:
Remove etcd.service dependency for flannel-config.service

If not remove etcd dependency for flannel-config, when etcd is not 
ready(but etcd will start success finally),the flannel-config service 
will excute failed,and not restart again

Actually,/usr/local/bin/flannel-config will  write flannel config when
etcd become ready,use

    "while ! curl -sf -L $ETCD_CURL_OPTIONS \
            $FLANNEL_ETCD_ENDPOINTS/v2/keys${FLANNEL_ETCD_PREFIX}/config
            -X PUT --data-urlencode value@${FLANNEL_JSON}; do
        echo "waiting for etcd"
        sleep 1
    done"

So let's remove this dependency

Change-Id: I5eb3faa6af89ade0301486470318193830e109cd

> (1 comment)

Renamed'}, {'account_id': 19741, 'date': '2017-11-14 02:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Seems like this patch is not correct, Nova installation docs use RegionOne instead of regionOne.
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/install/controller-install-ubuntu.html'}, {'account_id': 16365, 'date': '2017-11-14 02:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Seems like this patch is not correct, Nova installation docs use

 > https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/install/controller-install-ubuntu.html

OpenStack TripleO, RDO packstack, director do use regionOne'}, {'account_id': 16365, 'date': '2017-11-14 02:40:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Seems like this patch is not correct, Nova installation docs use
 > RegionOne instead of regionOne.
 > https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/install/controller-install-ubuntu.html

I just checked and Red Hat, CentOS do use regionOne not RegionOne. 

 > Seems like this patch is not correct, Nova installation docs use

doesn't look like a necessary update to me, better if you can send a mail out to collect all project`s opinion on how we want to deal about this"}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2018-01-23 21:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

From the commit message, I can't see what's the benefit to do the rename. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-10-07 21:28:56.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

[{'created': '2018-02-07 08:20:26.000000000', 'message': "Only allow pull from heat in os-collect-config

We for now, only use heat for os-collect-config, so we shouldn't
allow it to try to pull from other sources. That will increase

Change-Id: I6cb44c97c4f6ff685d78c19d4e33b3c811bfc43e
"}]
commit_message:
Only allow pull from heat in os-collect-config

We for now, only use heat for os-collect-config, so we shouldn't
allow it to try to pull from other sources. That will increase
unrequired (and undesired) bandwith.

Change-Id: I6cb44c97c4f6ff685d78c19d4e33b3c811bfc43e

commit_message:
[api-ref]Host name is not necessary to contain '@'

As shown in https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e39652d2dc8f4cb394933da8f9a9bb59/log/job-output.txt,
host name may contain '@', but not necessary to contain '@',
like:
Request (VolumeHostsV3RbacTest:test_show_host):
200 GET https://10.208.227.163/volume/v3/67d6a092ee7d4cd4a6b3ae37812bec50/os-hosts/ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010673901
Response Body: {"host":
                 [{"resource":
                   {"volume_count": "2", "total_volume_gb": "2",
                    "total_snapshot_gb": "1", "project": "(total)",
                    "host": "ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010673901",
                    "snapshot_count": "1"}},
                  {"resource":
                   {"volume_count": "1", "total_volume_gb": "1",
                     "total_snapshot_gb": "0",
                     "project": "2aba5d9825ac47a7b8c3ea805af34a75",
                     "host": "ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010673901",
                     "snapshot_count": "0"}}}

Besides, the format 'host@backend' should be that of host_name_backend,
not host.

Change-Id: Id2c0be1e4d0471686674ef781b722087638c4c50

commit_message:
Add context to cloning snapshots in remotefs driver

Adds context to _create_cloned_volume method in order
to allow taking a snapshot during cloning. Also saves
the temp_snapshot in order to enable Nova to update the
snapshot state. Destroys the temp_snapshot after usage.
This affects the NFS, WindowsSMBFS, VZStorage and
Quobyte drivers.

Closes-Bug: #1744692

Change-Id: I328a02d0f26e8c3d41ec18a0487da6fd20b39b04
(cherry picked from commit 78f2101fc5a84e81132e6c2adc89cfe681018d77)
(cherry picked from commit 247c6607156da6f4403c4826c7d2e09720c43e8d)

commit_message:
Don't allow retype to encrypted+multiattach type

This maintains consistency with our policy of not allowing the
combination of encryption and multiattach in commit
18327971ca7231807294a6b1dbf3d80c23cb6796

Change-Id: I1c22bc86d96bb1cab80c004d3450b1dac6c4a769
(cherry picked from commit 293be4f81b6b219e2651bc2f5b8b8c63b8883165)
(cherry picked from commit f6224a84a1f8051d2052af80211715ded59d79a1)
(cherry picked from commit 4adaa86f904f7071e0f8b79ee2e204d3d1a26fd1)

[{'created': '2019-08-13 20:16:31.000000000', 'message': "Fix ceph: only close rbd image after snapshot iteration is finished

list_snaps() returns an iterator object that requires resources from the
Image object. Closing the Image object deallocates these resources.

On Ceph mimic, which contains changes to the functions being invoked,
iterating over the snapshots of a closed image results in the following
assertion being triggered:

cinder-backup[29383]: /build/ceph-13.2.2/src/common/Mutex.cc: In function 'void Mutex::Lock(bool)' thread 7f35a4812700 time 2018-12-14 10:10:49.843120
cinder-backup[29383]: /build/ceph-13.2.2/src/common/Mutex.cc: 110: FAILED assert(r == 0)
cinder-backup[29383]:  ceph version 13.2.2 (02899bfda814146b021136e9d8e80eba494e1126) mimic (stable)
cinder-backup[29383]:  1: (ceph::__ceph_assert_fail(char const*, char const*, int, char const*)+0x102) [0x7f35903440f2]
cinder-backup[29383]:  2: (()+0x3162b7) [0x7f35903442b7]
cinder-backup[29383]:  3: (Mutex::Lock(bool)+0x1de) [0x7f359031901e]
cinder-backup[29383]:  4: (()+0x8f452) [0x7f358dafc452]
cinder-backup[29383]:  5: (()+0x11280d) [0x7f358db7f80d]
cinder-backup[29383]:  6: (rbd_snap_get_namespace_type()+0x29) [0x7f358dacf549]

The lock being tried to acquire and the object that contained it have
already been destroyed by closing the image. The assertion terminates
the cinder-backup service via SIGABRT.

On Ceph luminous we've seen occasional segfaults of the cinder-backup
service, which might have the same underlying cause.

Closes-Bug: #1838691

Change-Id: If6043d82cc57d9247a290816d90b95cdf719eaac
Signed-off-by: Sven Wegener <sven.wegener@inovex.de>
(cherry picked from commit 76569672599eda764f946ad6ee2ce0bdaddad36b)
(cherry picked from commit e78b220f448c7eb0de35aafd1d49b00547384d41)
(cherry picked from commit 57b127459189e39e993426f8e401e288f6394d4b)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ceph: only close rbd image after snapshot iteration is finished

list_snaps() returns an iterator object that requires resources from the
Image object. Closing the Image object deallocates these resources.

On Ceph mimic, which contains changes to the functions being invoked,
iterating over the snapshots of a closed image results in the following
assertion being triggered:

cinder-backup[29383]: /build/ceph-13.2.2/src/common/Mutex.cc: In function 'void Mutex::Lock(bool)' thread 7f35a4812700 time 2018-12-14 10:10:49.843120
cinder-backup[29383]: /build/ceph-13.2.2/src/common/Mutex.cc: 110: FAILED assert(r == 0)
cinder-backup[29383]:  ceph version 13.2.2 (02899bfda814146b021136e9d8e80eba494e1126) mimic (stable)
cinder-backup[29383]:  1: (ceph::__ceph_assert_fail(char const*, char const*, int, char const*)+0x102) [0x7f35903440f2]
cinder-backup[29383]:  2: (()+0x3162b7) [0x7f35903442b7]
cinder-backup[29383]:  3: (Mutex::Lock(bool)+0x1de) [0x7f359031901e]
cinder-backup[29383]:  4: (()+0x8f452) [0x7f358dafc452]
cinder-backup[29383]:  5: (()+0x11280d) [0x7f358db7f80d]
cinder-backup[29383]:  6: (rbd_snap_get_namespace_type()+0x29) [0x7f358dacf549]

The lock being tried to acquire and the object that contained it have
already been destroyed by closing the image. The assertion terminates
the cinder-backup service via SIGABRT.

On Ceph luminous we've seen occasional segfaults of the cinder-backup
service, which might have the same underlying cause.

Closes-Bug: #1838691

Change-Id: If6043d82cc57d9247a290816d90b95cdf719eaac
Signed-off-by: Sven Wegener <sven.wegener@inovex.de>
(cherry picked from commit 76569672599eda764f946ad6ee2ce0bdaddad36b)
(cherry picked from commit e78b220f448c7eb0de35aafd1d49b00547384d41)
(cherry picked from commit 57b127459189e39e993426f8e401e288f6394d4b)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26776, 'date': '2018-01-18 06:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Remove the deprecated "giturl" option

From openstackdocstheme 1.18.0, valid Git URLs can be retrieved by
openstackdocstheme[1], we do not need giturl option anymore.

commit_message:
Update DCOS to v1.10

The image is now build with Docker from CentOS repo.
Commit id updated to fetch the DC/OS 1.10.

Implements: blueprint mesos-dcos
Depends-On: I3b07da133daccabf12abc6b162bbe60fd33276ab

commit_message:
[suse] Add custom etcd service configuration based on static IPs

In specific scenarios without access to outside network. There will no be
possibility to use etcd discovery service from http://discovery.etcd.io. Â 
For this cases we have to initialize etcd cluster based on static IP's. Â 
Â 
To use this functionality, please setup --discovery-url as none during
creating Kubernetes cluster.

Change-Id: I458e716b96d2515fee7b8af2eee7027e21c11fa5
Partial-Bug: #1622949

commit_message:
Scaling down the node which runs less pods

When user scales down the nodes, the get_removal_nodes() of
scale_manager.py can not get the node which contains less pods.
This patch can delete the node which contains no pods firstly,
then delete the node which containes less pods.

Change-Id: I755afae294059ff53686824fff127127efc96fbc
Closes-Bug: #1600125

commit_message:
Make kubernetes backend support keystone v3

Kubernetes backend only support keystone v2 at this point,
make it support keystone v3.
Closes-Bug: #1645610

Change-Id: I7bc3ab8453eb4f20e523e3260ffedf33b64d4af9

(2 comments)

Hi, K8s does not povides CNI "instead" of Flannel. CNI have a Flannel integration/plugin that delegate networking to flannel.

CNI is not a Network Driver, Network drivers for Kubernetes (whether or not they integrate with CNI) are listed here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/admin/networking/#how-to-achieve-this

With this patch and the $NETWORK_DRIVER==CNI you are breaking Flannel and the overlay network between pods or i'm missing something.

I really don't see how is this going to work. It is true that Kubernetes supports CNI as it is now build in the hyperkube images. But CNI works with plugins. The simplest /de facto for kubernetes is flannel but you can use others.'}, {'account_id': 22493, 'date': '2017-02-18 08:47:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1'}, {'account_id': 22493, 'date': '2017-02-18 08:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-02-18 09:43:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

You need to do this on both master and minion, you also need to add a default CNI configuration in /etc/cni/net.d, for example with flannel it is something like that :
{
    "name": "podnet",
    "type": "flannel",
    "delegate": {
        "isDefaultGateway": true
    }
}'}, {'account_id': 22493, 'date': '2017-02-21 01:02:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The cni configuration is specified by user, you don't know specific configuration to use. We can't find common cni configuration as default.'}, {'account_id': 22493, 'date': '2017-02-25 03:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

 > > > {
 > > > "name": "podnet",
 > > > "type": "flannel",
 > > > "delegate": {
 > > > "isDefaultGateway": true
 > > > }
 > > > }
 > >
 > > the kubelet args of master contain --register-schedulable=false,
 > so
 > > the pod is not scheduled to master, don't need config cni in
 > master
 > 
 > You need CNI on master too, you have kubernetes system pods running
 > on master. Also your default configuration is a bridge one bt the
 > default driver for Kube in magnum is flannel

kubernetes system pods use host network, for example, you can see "hostNetwork: true
" in /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-controller-manager.yaml. Flannel is not a container network that can not be seen by pod.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-11 23:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

commit_message:
magnum support cni network driver

As known, k8s can provide cni network plugin for containers,
but magnum can not support config cni for coe k8s.
We add --network-plugin=cni to kubelet command line in configure-
kubernetes-minions.
More informations about cni network plugin can be
seen in https://kubernetes.io/docs/admin/network-plugins.

Change-Id: Icf66a9f287a215bacc2fa03c983e3383bf3faaee
Implements: blueprint magnum-support-cni-network-driver

Did some work making links for v1 point to strictly v1 endpoints.
Had an issue with the make_link function because of the bookmark parameter, so removed it and the logic that used it. 
The drawback to this means labeling IDs for making links as explicit versions for any previous version (i.e. calling make_link with "v1/clusters" for v1). This could be seen as smelly code so I'm open to suggestions to make it nicer.

Updated v1 tests to account for the new output. Next step is either: (1) converting v1 tests to become "new" v2 tests while also reverting the link tests to check for bookmarks without "v2", or (2) start adding plausible functionality to v2 API'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-22 20:05:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
[WIP] Add NodeGroups with v2 API

Adds v2 API folder structure including cluster,
cluster_template, and adding nodegroup files. Mostly a
sandbox implementation for now. Adds some /v1 functions
via /v2 path for ClusterTemplate.

Change-Id: I253937140b4d409384cedf4e5754386ff796ceee
Implements: blueprint nodegroups

subject: Allow deletion of clusters with unsupported driver

My concern is about leaving orphaned resources in the system that will have to be deleted manually.  In a production system with thousands of clusters, this would not be a good thing for operators to have to handle.
Looking at the scenarios:

(1) Cluster with non-existent driver:  the previous patch already prevents this from happening.  If we are sure that there is no other way for cluster to sneak in with non-existent driver, then maybe we don't need to worry about this scenario.

(2) Handle clusters created before the patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/387748/ where the cluster delete code is moved to the driver:  it seems we are kind of stuck here, because there is no longer a patch to call the cluster_delete code.  We may just have to delete the heat stack manually and then use this patch to delete the cluster entry in Magnum.  Hopefully this is a one-time occurrence and it's not too painful.  The heat stack can be found using the name of the cluster, so make sure to delete the stack before the cluster.

(3) Uninstalling driver:  this scenario is more problematic since it will be recurring in the future, and we really want to avoid leaving orphaned resources by just deleting the Magnum entry.  It's great that we uncover the problem here, and a complete solution will require more than this patch.  We can consider the following:

-In this patch, check for sign that resources are still associated with this cluster, for instance a Heat stack ID that does exist in Heat.  If so, log an error pointing to the existing resources and don't delete the cluster.

-Document the practice for uninstalling a driver:  make sure no cluster of this driver type still exists.  To help with this, we can add a filter to cluster-list to select cluster of a driver type.

-When restarting the conductor for the uninstalled driver to take effect, scan the clusters to make sure they are supported by the new set of drivers.  Log an error and exit if unsupported driver is detected.  This will force the operator to reinstall the driver and clean up the clusters.

I am sure there are other techniques, so it would be good to hear additional suggestions."}, {'account_id': 15123, 'date': '2017-02-16 22:54:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

> My concern is about leaving orphaned resources in the system that
 > will have to be deleted manually.  In a production system with
 > thousands of clusters, this would not be a good thing for operators
 > to have to handle.
 > Looking at the scenarios:
 > 
 > (1) Cluster with non-existent driver:  the previous patch already
 > prevents this from happening.  If we are sure that there is no
 > other way for cluster to sneak in with non-existent driver, then
 > maybe we don't need to worry about this scenario.
 
Perhaps there would be a scenario where a cluster was created, then the driver was uninstalled and couldn't be reinstalled or became unusable. This is pure conjecture, but from my experience working with heat there were times when something got messed up and I really wished that I could just delete a stack without having to go into the DB. Manually cleaning up the resources was always much easier and less worrisome than DB surgery. Just something to consider.

 > (2) Handle clusters created before the patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/387748/
 > where the cluster delete code is moved to the driver: <snip>

I don't think that this patch actually affects this issue. Clusters created before and after the patch aren't different.

 > (3) Uninstalling driver:  this scenario is more problematic since
 > it will be recurring in the future, and we really want to avoid
 > leaving orphaned resources by just deleting the Magnum entry.  It's
 > great that we uncover the problem here, and a complete solution
 > will require more than this patch.  We can consider the following:
 > 
 > -In this patch, check for sign that resources are still associated
 > with this cluster, for instance a Heat stack ID that does exist in
 > Heat.  If so, log an error pointing to the existing resources and
 > don't delete the cluster.
 
Without the driver, the magnum engine can't make any assumptions about the resources backing the Cluster since drivers can now use any service, not just heat.

 > -Document the practice for uninstalling a driver:  make sure no
 > cluster of this driver type still exists.  To help with this, we
 > can add a filter to cluster-list to select cluster of a driver
 > type.
 > 
 > -When restarting the conductor for the uninstalled driver to take
 > effect, scan the clusters to make sure they are supported by the
 > new set of drivers.  Log an error and exit if unsupported driver is
 > detected.  This will force the operator to reinstall the driver and
 > clean up the clusters.
 
I would at least want a way for the operator to bypass this if needed because I don't like the risk of the service going down for an extended period of time because of an unforseen problem with reinstalling the driver. A degraded service is probably better than no service at all, and I would think that operator should be able to make that call.

 > I am sure there are other techniques, so it would be good to hear
 > additional suggestions.

I think that clusters can end up in an undeletable state in a myriad of ways that are out of magnum's control, such as a bug in a driver, a driver being uninstalled, or a downstream service being removed. I think that it would be very useful to have a method for those times where you need to tell magnum "sorry, for whatever reason you can't handle deleting a cluster the normal way, I just need you to purge it from the DB". I think that the operator can be trusted to know when this is necessary, so I propose adding a --force flag to *-delete methods with a separate policy that can be set to admin-only.'}, {'account_id': 15123, 'date': '2017-02-16 22:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The quoting turned out horribly. 2nd try.


 > > My concern is about leaving orphaned resources in the system that
 > > will have to be deleted manually.  In a production system with
 > > thousands of clusters, this would not be a good thing for
 > > operators
 > > to have to handle.
 > > Looking at the scenarios:
 > >
 > > (1) Cluster with non-existent driver:  the previous patch already
 > > prevents this from happening.  If we are sure that there is no
 > > other way for cluster to sneak in with non-existent driver, then
 > > maybe we don't need to worry about this scenario.



Perhaps there would be a scenario where a cluster was created, then
the driver was uninstalled and couldn't be reinstalled or became
unusable. This is pure conjecture, but from my experience working
with heat there were times when something got messed up and I
really wished that I could just delete a stack without having to go
into the DB. Manually cleaning up the resources was always much
easier and less worrisome than DB surgery. Just something to
consider.



 > > (2) Handle clusters created before the patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/387748/
 > > where the cluster delete code is moved to the driver: <snip>



I don't think that this patch actually affects this issue. Clusters
created before and after the patch aren't different.



 > > (3) Uninstalling driver:  this scenario is more problematic since
 > > it will be recurring in the future, and we really want to avoid
 > > leaving orphaned resources by just deleting the Magnum entry. 
 > > It's
 > > great that we uncover the problem here, and a complete solution
 > > will require more than this patch.  We can consider the
 > > following:
 > >
 > > -In this patch, check for sign that resources are still
 > > associated
 > > with this cluster, for instance a Heat stack ID that does exist
 > > in
 > > Heat.  If so, log an error pointing to the existing resources and
 > > don't delete the cluster.



Without the driver, the magnum engine can't make any assumptions
about the resources backing the Cluster since drivers can now use
any service, not just heat.



 > > -Document the practice for uninstalling a driver:  make sure no
 > > cluster of this driver type still exists.  To help with this, we
 > > can add a filter to cluster-list to select cluster of a driver
 > > type.
 > >
 > > -When restarting the conductor for the uninstalled driver to take
 > > effect, scan the clusters to make sure they are supported by the
 > > new set of drivers.  Log an error and exit if unsupported driver
 > > is
 > > detected.  This will force the operator to reinstall the driver
 > > and
 > > clean up the clusters.



I would at least want a way for the operator to bypass this if
needed because I don't like the risk of the service going down for
an extended period of time because of an unforseen problem with
reinstalling the driver. A degraded service is probably better than
no service at all, and I would think that operator should be able
to make that call.



 > > I am sure there are other techniques, so it would be good to hear
 > > additional suggestions.



I think that clusters can end up in an undeletable state in a
myriad of ways that are out of magnum's control, such as a bug in a
driver, a driver being uninstalled, or a downstream service being
removed. I think that it would be very useful to have a method for
those times where you need to tell magnum "sorry, for whatever
reason you can't handle deleting a cluster the normal way, I just
need you to purge it from the DB". I think that the operator can be
trusted to know when this is necessary, so I propose adding a
--force flag to *-delete methods with a separate policy that can be
set to admin-only.'}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2017-02-16 23:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

+1 on avoiding DB surgery, as I have had to do this on a customer production system and it was no fun.  Ultimately, we want to help the operators manage the system in a way that is as painless as possible, in the face of unexpected failures and errors.  So, gathering lessons learned from  experience would be very useful to find the best solution.  

The -force option on cluster-delete is a reasonable way to at least manage Magnum DB, leaving out the question of managing the actual resources.  Having to specify this option would signal to the operator:  "use with care, you know what you are doing".'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 04:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-10-07 21:14:58.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Hi, I'm going to abandon this by doing an overall project cleanup. Please feel free to reopen this. Thanks."}]

commit_message:
WIP: Improving Error Handling

When cloud-init scripts fail, magnum does not convey to API users
what went wrong during the failed cluster create attempt.

This patch demonstrates how to use a heat waitcondition
to surface the reason. This tests for basic name resolution and
network connectivity for the API endpoints. If these tests fail,
then so will the cluster create process.

This short circuits the cluster create processing so the error
is surfaced in the first few seconds of processing, rather
than waiting for a timeout to elapse.

Change-Id: Ib68038e1ce76e761a4dac5146b6a13ed49d0e55c
Partial-Bug: 1669056

commit_message:
Update Dev Quickstart for Xenial

The current quickstart says it is only tested for ubuntu 14.04
(trustry) but the current devstack no longer works with trusty.
This patch updates the quickstart guide iwith working instructions
for Ubuntu 16.04.2 (Xenial).

Change-Id: If4c4630bb7b634147920e98eeb4cf9bd43bb08c1
Closes-Bug: #1677399

- gate-functional-dsvm-magnum-k8s-ironic-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/30/460330/1/check/gate-functional-dsvm-magnum-k8s-ironic-ubuntu-xenial-nv/6e49a40/ : FAILURE in 20m 47s (non-voting)
- gate-magnum-tox-migration-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/460330/1/check/gate-magnum-tox-migration-ubuntu-xenial/20d542f/ : FAILURE in 1m 27s (non-voting)
- magnum-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/30/460330/1/check/magnum-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv/c7bddf9/ : SUCCESS in 4m 59s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2017-04-27 17:48:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

We had a discussion for this kind of change a long time ago in this review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/315178/

See comment the relates comment:

There might be other use cases to pass a per baymodel cert, but isn't the magnum endpoint the same for all bays? If yes this could be set once in the templates, without needing an extra baymodel param. There's a blueprint to allow something like that:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/allow-user-softwareconfig

Even that bp has been superseded because it adds a parameter to cluster-template which is a deployment wide parameter.

If you want to pass something to the cluster you can modify your cluster driver and add the certs you want, you can even have it configurable with a label specific for your driver only. For example, we solve this problem by modifying the driver like so:
https://gitlab.cern.ch/cloud-infrastructure/magnum/blob/cern-newton/magnum/drivers/k8s_fedora_atomic_v1/templates/kubemaster.yaml#L401

Adding blindly fields to cluster-template proved to be a very bad practice.

Feel free to ping me on IRC or any other member to discuss it."}, {'account_id': 10992, 'date': '2017-05-01 19:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10992, 'date': '2017-05-01 19:20:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Spyros,

I'll try to connect to IRC, having some problems with this now.

I removed ext_ca field from cluster template model. External CA certs are installed from local file which is specified through config file setting. The reason why I'm proposing this is that we need openstack user to be able to try standard types of clusters, without writing his own template extensions."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-05-01 20:39:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

[{'created': '2017-04-26 21:48:12.000000000', 'message': "Add external CA certs to cluster template

Magnum requires that a cluster connects to different public API's
(Identity API for trustee user authentication, Magnum API for
certificate storing, Heat API for wait condition notification, etc).
If API endpoint is configured with HTTPS, connection will fail server
certificate validation, unless public API is configured with
commercial TLS certificate, issued by CA from Mozilla approved CA list.

This patch allows passing in of an optional CA certificate to cluster
template, which can be used for server certificate validation when
connecting to public URLs. This cert will be passed into the cluster
at creation time and added to the CA bundle.

An associated patch will be included for magnumclient to upload a cert.
THis review supecedes https://review.openstack.org/315178

Change-Id: Ic9cb2f0f25f7bbfe8e14b1a72fab6d5002518aac
Closes-Bug: 1580704
"}, {'created': '2017-05-01 19:07:55.000000000', 'message': "Add external CA certs to cluster template

certificate validation, unless public API is configured with

This patch introduces a new setting add_ext_ca_cert in [cluster]
section of magnum.conf file. Content of this file will be passed into
cluster nodes at creation time and added to the CA bundle.

CA certificate injection is implemented for k8s_atomic, k8s_coreos,
swarm-atomic and ubuntu_mesos. For k8s_opensuse and k8s_ironic, only
parameter was added to parent template to avoid InvalidParameterValue
error. Implementation is to be added separately.

This review supecedes https://review.openstack.org/315178

commit_message:
Add external CA certs to cluster template

Magnum requires that cluster connects to different public API's
(Identity API for trustee user authentication, Magnum API for
certificate storing, Heat API for wait condition notification, etc).
If API endpoint is configured with HTTPS, connection will fail server
certificate validation, unless public API is configured with
commercial TLS certificate, issued by CA from Mozilla approved CA list.

This patch introduces a new setting add_ext_ca_cert in [cluster]
section of magnum.conf file. Content of this file will be passed into
cluster nodes at creation time and added to the CA bundle.

CA certificate injection is implemented for k8s_atomic, k8s_coreos,
swarm-atomic and ubuntu_mesos. For k8s_opensuse and k8s_ironic, only
parameter was added to parent template to avoid InvalidParameterValue
error. Implementation is to be added separately.

This review supecedes https://review.openstack.org/315178

Change-Id: Ic9cb2f0f25f7bbfe8e14b1a72fab6d5002518aac
Closes-Bug: 1580704

commit_message:
Make sure the wsgi script dir mode is 0755

When the system-wide umask setting is more restrictive than the
default setting, the wsgi script directory permissions may not allow
the apache process to access them, resulting in errors.

A similar fix was applied to Keystone some time ago, see [1].

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/4f15fb64b1cb60388efbee75acbfb3b13a8fa1f6

Change-Id: Ie9769657dc530bc895a3119b3e458864a8b5f293
(cherry picked from commit 33b05434f3e17f394ec1a39959adcfd46d361e06)
(cherry picked from commit e2e70bb6b927944e8dc3dd2ea587257055953fa5)

(cherry picked from commit 9573487cf169df8011fa666c9b0d7f4e910bcaac)

commit_message:
Make sure the wsgi script dir mode is 0755

When the system-wide umask setting is more restrictive than the
default setting, the wsgi script directory permissions may not allow
the apache process to access them, resulting in errors.

A similar fix was applied to Keystone some time ago, see [1].

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/4f15fb64b1cb60388efbee75acbfb3b13a8fa1f6

Change-Id: Ie9769657dc530bc895a3119b3e458864a8b5f293
(cherry picked from commit 33b05434f3e17f394ec1a39959adcfd46d361e06)
(cherry picked from commit e2e70bb6b927944e8dc3dd2ea587257055953fa5)
(cherry picked from commit c42d912bc496daf4811a6933ff0accdb234bc158)

subject: Restore defaults for combine and failonfail in openstack command
messages: [{'account_id': 13294, 'date': '2019-09-18 08:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-10-07 21:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\npike should no longer be patched'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-18 08:13:18.000000000', 'message': 'Restore defaults for combine and failonfail in openstack command

[1] added "override_locale: false" to the openstack command executions,
to respect the current locale. This had an unintended side effect,
since it changed the values for failonfail and combine to false in
that same execution, as described in [2].

We should ensure that openstack command failures are respected, so
this commit restores that behavior.

[1] - https://review.opendev.org/640997
[2] - https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/util/execution.rb#L139-L143

Change-Id: I55e587ea5c83338ae989aa56f1f379079eb02e08
(cherry picked from commit 726b06cdb49426719a13be3f02bcce72a697484c)
'}]
commit_message:
Restore defaults for combine and failonfail in openstack command

[1] added "override_locale: false" to the openstack command executions,
to respect the current locale. This had an unintended side effect,
since it changed the values for failonfail and combine to false in
that same execution, as described in [2].

We should ensure that openstack command failures are respected, so
this commit restores that behavior.

[1] - https://review.opendev.org/640997
[2] - https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppet/blob/master/lib/puppet/util/execution.rb#L139-L143

Change-Id: I55e587ea5c83338ae989aa56f1f379079eb02e08
(cherry picked from commit 726b06cdb49426719a13be3f02bcce72a697484c)

commit_message:
[suse] Disable iptables rules created by Docker

All iptables rules created by Docker are useless,
when K8s networking is in place. We have to disable
iptables rules created by Docker in K8s cluster.

Change-Id: I1f7613678a29b016276d7fc23949b7cd09f34652
Closes-Bug: #1668569

commit_message:
PowerMax Docs Stein - clarifying information

1.  The note is not applicable to Stein as the fix was made before Stein GA.
2.  Decision was made to extend VMAX Hybrid support beyond Train.
This clarification is applicable only to Stein.

'}]
commit_message:
Update default ref name for Gitea

With the change from CGIT to Gitea, branch refs need to be passed
differently. Unfortunately we missed correcting the default value
for falling back to the master branch. Correct it now.

Change-Id: I5233ede99f7f522425b7f553b26115bdcaa787ce

commit_message:
Added os-brick adjustments in the Image Encryption spec

A description for the changes in os-brick is added to this spec.

Change-Id: Icc5a393b6ed5ab162d2456531500de0508949251
Co-Authored-By: Markus Hentsch <markus.hentsch@secustack.com>

commit_message:
Rollback the volume_types table when failed to update quota_usages

We create a new volume based on a volume type, then update the volume
type name to a new name of 255 characters in length.
When updating the volume type table, the quota_usages table is updated
synchronously. If DB error occurs in the quota_usages table, we need to
roll back the volume types table.Otherwise, when the volume is deleted,
the information of the quota_usages table will not be updated.

Closes-bug: #1802430
Related-Bug: #1608849

Change-Id: I040ccde7f04ae39258afd9b7322c939c8d796bde

Agree on the point that backup_compression_algorithm doesn't strictly needs to be case sensitive.
However, the current problem faced is between "None" and "none" option only.
Making all the compression algo names case insensitive won't harm but to be on the safe side,
we can just edit the docs and update None -> none (Simplest solution)
But i've my agreement on this approach too.'}, {'account_id': 25678, 'date': '2019-04-09 16:19:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I do think we should make this change. It's a very subtle and confusing thing for someone that is not aware of the case sensitivity.

In addition to this though, I've proposed https://review.openstack.org/651619 to update the docs so we are at least not giving the wrong example."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-04-10 18:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

I agree with Sean on this one.  We've been converting the supplied value to lowercase for longer than we've disallowed it:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blame/698b522a57a66f902c6bfcab91a00a62006207fb/cinder/backup/chunkeddriver.py#L395

The disallow happened 2 years ago:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/commit/658588adc3e824750c90f364657fcdb06068abb5
when that eharney guy (!) added the enumeration (I suspect oslo.config didn't have the ignore case option at that point).  But the key thing, I think, is we have users running OpenStacks older than 2 years, it would be nice not to break their config when they upgrade."}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2019-04-10 19:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Eric Harney <eharney@redhat.com>

Disaling compression is done by setting the
backup_compression_algorithm config option to None. The valid values is
has the option of "none" but our documentation stated "None". This
caused an error, but should be allowed.

Closes-bug: #1823852

commit_message:
Make backup_compression_algorithm case insensitive

Disaling compression is done by setting the
backup_compression_algorithm config option to None. The valid values is
has the option of "none" but our documentation stated "None". This
caused an error, but should be allowed.

Closes-bug: #1823852

Change-Id: I5ae6e715117d0e89a9d2641602f6b70a0ce94c69
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

Async migration is used in the process of creating a volume from a
snapshot and an internal temp snapshot is created.

Because the temp snapshot isn't deleted, the LUN hosting the temp
snapshot cannot be deleted from the VNX storage.

For example, a new volume, V2, is created from snapshot S1 of volume V1.
An internal temp snapshot S2 is created from copying S1. V1 now has two
snapshots, S1 and S2. Although we delete V1, V2 and S1 from Cinder,
S2 which is Cinder user-invisible isn't deleted and which causes V1 left
on VNX too.

The fix makes sure the snapshot S2 is deleted. Then the delay deletion
on V1 can be executed successfully.

commit_message:
VNX: delete the LUN from VNX backend

Async migration is used in the process of creating a volume from a
snapshot and an internal temp snapshot is created.

Because the temp snapshot isn't deleted, the LUN hosting the temp
snapshot cannot be deleted from the VNX storage.

For example, a new volume, V2, is created from snapshot S1 of volume V1.
An internal temp snapshot S2 is created from copying S1. V1 now has two
snapshots, S1 and S2. Although we delete V1, V2 and S1 from Cinder,
S2 which is Cinder user-invisible isn't deleted and which causes V1 left
on VNX too.

The fix makes sure the snapshot S2 is deleted. Then the delay deletion
on V1 can be executed successfully.

Change-Id: Ib86729488ebfb0aea5d5d4f815a64e00258040e7
Closes-bug: #1794646

Sphinx 2.0 is more strict on enforcing proper format for the specified
code type. This resulted in a few warnings due to JSON code blocks not
being valid JSON. This cleans up a few cases that were not properly
formatted.

Closes-bug: #1822891

Change-Id: Id6fa50b759add5d2286b98f1752a7ff92bf0515d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix code-block JSON format issues

Sphinx 2.0 is more strict on enforcing proper format for the specified
code type. This resulted in a few warnings due to JSON code blocks not
being valid JSON. This cleans up a few cases that were not properly
formatted.

Closes-bug: #1822891

Change-Id: Id6fa50b759add5d2286b98f1752a7ff92bf0515d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

* Lenovo-iSCSI http://os-logs.tristero.net/lenovo-ci/68/630068/1/Lenovo-iSCSI : FAILURE in 4:17:04'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-01-16 10:21:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Something doesn't seem right.
If the child is actually inheriting the service_id, then it's also inheriting the manager stored in `self.manager`, and therefore will not be using the right AZ, backend, or anything.
So this patch wouldn't actually solve the problem.
Could you confirm, please?"}, {'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2019-01-16 16:46:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> Something doesn't seem right.
 > If the child is actually inheriting the service_id, then it's also
 > inheriting the manager stored in `self.manager`, and therefore will
 > not be using the right AZ, backend, or anything.
 > So this patch wouldn't actually solve the problem.
 > Could you confirm, please?

We create the service in [1] with the right args, and these info would be stored
in server, and when we launch service, will generate the wrap [2], and it would
be cached in wrap [3], and when we respawning the service, this wrap would be
pop [4], and restart with right info [5].

But unfortunately, the serice_id is the class attr, the parent process
refreshes the service_id when start service [6], and finally if we don't refresh this id
when re-spawning (in start()), we will get the wrong service.

So, we need refresh the service_id  when we start the child service.

Sorry to forget to add bug link, in commit msg, the problem is easy to reproduce,
and I write it in [7]. Hope I describe this issue clearly.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/cmd/volume.py#L101
[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L597
[3] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L584
[4] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L634
[5] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L648
[6] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L193
[7] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1811344"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-01-16 17:03:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for the detailed explanation, though I admit that at this time I don't have the whole flow in my head.
In any case, couldn't we just store the service_id on __init__ also in the instance and then recover from it?
Is there any specific method on the Service that gets called only when it's respawning the service?  If there is we could set the class attribute back using the instance attribute."}, {'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2019-01-17 02:22:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Thank you for the detailed explanation, though I admit that at this
 > time I don't have the whole flow in my head.
 > In any case, couldn't we just store the service_id on __init__ also
 > in the instance and then recover from it?
 > Is there any specific method on the Service that gets called only
 > when it's respawning the service?  If there is we could set the
 > class attribute back using the instance attribute.

Yes, it's the alternate way, and I also considered this way, but we should add a redundant attr in Service (something like self.origin_service_id).

But I think the way your mentioned can avoid a db query to get service obj, so I agree it's better, I will update soon in next patch. :)

[{'created': '2019-01-11 08:53:15.000000000', 'message': 'Refresh the Service.service_id after re-spawning children

Currently, the oslo.service provider a mechanism that the main process
will re-spawn the children as necessary. But if we kill the children
service, the services (except the latest service) are always down
after re-spawn.

This reason of this problem is that the Service.service_id is inherited
from the parent process [1] (the parent Service service id class
attribute) and has been recorded as the last created service [2][3]
when latest process is stared. But when re-spawning child process,
only start() method would be called[1], so that the Service.service_id
is not refreshed as expected.

In order to refresh the Service class attribute service_id, we
should get service from db, and then reset the Service.service_id
in child process.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L648
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L193
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L344

Change-Id: Ibefda81215c5081634876a2064b15638388ae921
Closes-bug: #1811344
'}, {'created': '2019-01-17 02:24:21.000000000', 'message': 'Refresh the Service.service_id after re-spawning children

Currently, the oslo.service provider a mechanism that the main process
will re-spawn the children as necessary. But if we kill the children
service, the services (except the latest service) are always down
after re-spawn.

This reason of this problem is that the Service.service_id is inherited
from the parent process [1] (the parent Service service id class
attribute) and has been recorded as the last created service [2][3]
when latest process is stared. But when re-spawning child process,
only start() method would be called[1], so that the Service.service_id
is not refreshed as expected.

In order to refresh the Service class attribute service_id, we
should store the service_id in instance attr origin_service_id, and set
the class attr back using the instance attribute in start method.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L648
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L193
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L344

Change-Id: Ibefda81215c5081634876a2064b15638388ae921
Closes-bug: #1811344
'}]
commit_message:
Refresh the Service.service_id after re-spawning children

Currently, the oslo.service provider a mechanism that the main process
will re-spawn the children as necessary. But if we kill the children
service, the services (except the latest service) are always down
after re-spawn.

This reason of this problem is that the Service.service_id is inherited
from the parent process [1] (the parent Service service id class
attribute) and has been recorded as the last created service [2][3]
when latest process is stared. But when re-spawning child process,
only start() method would be called[1], so that the Service.service_id
is not refreshed as expected.

In order to refresh the Service class attribute service_id, we
should store the service_id in instance attr origin_service_id, and set
the class attr back using the instance attribute in start method.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.service/blob/d987a4a/oslo_service/service.py#L648
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L193
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/099b141/cinder/service.py#L344

Change-Id: Ibefda81215c5081634876a2064b15638388ae921
Closes-bug: #1811344

commit_message:
Fix CI

This combines the following two patches which need to be landed together
to fix the stable branches. Additionally disable beaker until we can
land this patch.

Pin rake

rake 13.0.0 requires ruby 2.1.0.

Closes-Bug: #1845649
(cherry picked from commit 05ab5cc248a5708036ed27ae13a6f5d5e3bb8d1d)

Pin minitest

minitest 5.12.1[1] requires ruby ~>2.3.

[1] https://rubygems.org/gems/minitest/versions/5.12.1

Closes-Bug: #1845785
(cherry picked from commit 574c5bfd3bb645edd6b180e6d36b44e9beb10d77)

Change-Id: I4fca85f29fe1984707d500e1b87a0227cf4779dc

commit_message:
fix logger names

Most files are using getLogger(__name__) so that logging statements
are associated with the file they came from, but there are several
places where this practice has not been followed. This changes to
use __name__ consistently for most code. Per review comments,
commands and wsgi apps are instead updated to use the command/app
name.

Change-Id: Ic2594b88dd818df5486800e4759848d43edc24d1

commit_message:
Fix CI

This combines the following two patches which need to be landed together
to fix the stable branches. Additionally disable beaker until we can
land this patch.

Pin rake

rake 13.0.0 requires ruby 2.1.0.

Closes-Bug: #1845649
(cherry picked from commit 05ab5cc248a5708036ed27ae13a6f5d5e3bb8d1d)

Pin minitest

minitest 5.12.1[1] requires ruby ~>2.3.

[1] https://rubygems.org/gems/minitest/versions/5.12.1

Closes-Bug: #1845785
(cherry picked from commit 574c5bfd3bb645edd6b180e6d36b44e9beb10d77)

Change-Id: I4fca85f29fe1984707d500e1b87a0227cf4779dc

commit_message:
Deployment host can provide shibboleth SP key-pair

If you don't want to generate shibboleth SP key-pair on first playbook run
You can provide sp-cert.pem and sp-key.pem in /etc/openstack_deploy/keystone/

Change-Id: I6fb099cee10ef76f2cd6d20a03ffe53f45a1f85d
Signed-off-by: Kourosh Vivan <kourosh.vivan@osones.com>

commit_message:
Fix CI

This combines the following two patches which need to be landed together
to fix the stable branches. Additionally disable beaker until we can
land this patch.

Pin rake

rake 13.0.0 requires ruby 2.1.0.

Closes-Bug: #1845649
(cherry picked from commit 05ab5cc248a5708036ed27ae13a6f5d5e3bb8d1d)

Pin minitest

minitest 5.12.1[1] requires ruby ~>2.3.

[1] https://rubygems.org/gems/minitest/versions/5.12.1

Closes-Bug: #1845785
(cherry picked from commit 574c5bfd3bb645edd6b180e6d36b44e9beb10d77)

Change-Id: I4fca85f29fe1984707d500e1b87a0227cf4779dc

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-06 22:45:46.000000000', 'message': 'Modify nova routing table to process null requests

The nova client RESTful API requests of '' (NULL), '/', and
'/versions/{id}' are routed to the "{'GET': [version_controller,
'show']}" method by the first three entries of the nova server routing
table. Entries two and three do it explicitly, but NULL requests cause
an HTML redirect that results in the nova client issuing a new request
intended to match entry two ('/'). This redirection can return an
invalid target URL, specifically when an SSL termination proxy is
employed, causing the nova client to raise an exception of "Unable to
establish connection to <invalid URL>: ('Connection aborted.',
BadStatusLine("''",))".

This commit makes the following changes:

1. Elimination of HTTP 302 redirection for a '' (NULL) version request.
The first entry of the nova server routing table is modified to handle
a '' (NULL) request explicitly by replacing it with a modified copy of
the second entry; the new first entry has a path of '' (NULL), whereas
the second entry has a path of '/'.

2. The nova server version controller uses a special case to map
'/' version requests to the "index" action. This change also maps ''
(NULL) requests to the "index" action.

3. The nova API request function returns an invalid "application_url"
of "http://<fqdn>/v2" when processing a '' (NULL) version list request,
but not for other requests. A new special case was added to the version
view to provide the correct "application_url" of  "http://<fqdn>"

4. The changes above caused the following two nova API unit tests to
fail because the expected behavior has changed:

  o VersionsTestV21.test_get_version_list_302
  o VersionsTestV21WithV2CompatibleWrapper.test_get_version_list_302

This commit replaces and renames the two failing unit tests with two
tests for the new behavior. The two replacement tests are named:

  o VersionsTestV21.test_get_version_list_noslash
  o VersionsTestV21WithV2CompatibleWrapper.test_get_version_list_noslash

In both cases, instead of an HTTP 302 redirect to '/' (get versions
list), these tests expect an identical response for a '' (NULL) and a
'/' request, ie. HTTP 200 with a body containing a list of versions.

Change-Id: I24a5421c827312dec476d19b3d92584c6f1e27b3
Closes-Bug: 1728732
'}, {'created': '2017-11-07 16:32:42.000000000', 'message': 'Modify nova routing table to process null requests

commit_message:
Modify nova routing table to process null requests

The nova client RESTful API requests of '' (NULL), '/', and
'/versions/{id}' are routed to the "{'GET': [version_controller,
'show']}" method by the first three entries of the nova server routing
table. Entries two and three do it explicitly, but NULL requests cause
an HTML redirect that results in the nova client issuing a new request
intended to match entry two ('/'). This redirection can return an
invalid target URL, specifically when an SSL termination proxy is
employed, causing the nova client to raise an exception of "Unable to
establish connection to <invalid URL>: ('Connection aborted.',
BadStatusLine("''",))".

This commit makes the following changes:

1. Elimination of HTTP 302 redirection for a '' (NULL) version request.
The first entry of the nova server routing table is modified to handle
a '' (NULL) request explicitly by replacing it with a modified copy of
the second entry; the new first entry has a path of '' (NULL), whereas
the second entry has a path of '/'.

2. The nova server version controller uses a special case to map
'/' version requests to the "index" action. This change also maps ''
(NULL) requests to the "index" action.

3. The nova API request function returns an invalid "application_url"
of "http://<fqdn>/v2" when processing a '' (NULL) version list request,
but not for other requests. A new special case was added to the version
view to provide the correct "application_url" of  "http://<fqdn>"

4. The changes above caused the following two nova API unit tests to
fail because the expected behavior has changed:

  o VersionsTestV21.test_get_version_list_302
  o VersionsTestV21WithV2CompatibleWrapper.test_get_version_list_302

This commit replaces and renames the two failing unit tests with two
tests for the new behavior. The two replacement tests are named:

  o VersionsTestV21.test_get_version_list_noslash
  o VersionsTestV21WithV2CompatibleWrapper.test_get_version_list_noslash

In both cases, instead of an HTTP 302 redirect to '/' (get versions
list), these tests expect an identical response for a '' (NULL) and a
'/' request, ie. HTTP 200 with a body containing a list of versions.

Change-Id: I24a5421c827312dec476d19b3d92584c6f1e27b3
Closes-Bug: 1728732

in nova-network is disabled.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-02 16:21:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Another swing at `spy`

This one makes the calling environment behave a lot more like a normal
mock.

WIP: a real commit message

Change-Id: Ib387822ae20e2e68489680ff4cfeab20d0cf57bf
'}, {'created': '2019-10-02 22:54:22.000000000', 'message': 'Add a way to spy on function calls in test

With the mock lib we can replace functions with mocks and execute
arbitrary callables instead of the mocked function. But there is no
easy way to call the original function while the test spies on the
call.

This patch adds a spy context manager that allows executing arbitrary
callables before and after a function from the system under test.

The context manager returns an object that can be used to track data
across calls, including from within the `before` and `after` callables.
The tracker also has a subset of the semantics of a mock, in that calls
are tracked (properties like call_count, methods like assert_has_calls,
etc.)

Co-Authored-By: Balazs Gibizer <balazs.gibizer@est.tech>

Change-Id: Ib387822ae20e2e68489680ff4cfeab20d0cf57bf
'}]
commit_message:
Add a way to spy on function calls in test

With the mock lib we can replace functions with mocks and execute
arbitrary callables instead of the mocked function. But there is no
easy way to call the original function while the test spies on the
call.

This patch adds a spy context manager that allows executing arbitrary
callables before and after a function from the system under test.

The context manager returns an object that can be used to track data
across calls, including from within the `before` and `after` callables.
The tracker also has a subset of the semantics of a mock, in that calls
are tracked (properties like call_count, methods like assert_has_calls,
etc.)

Co-Authored-By: Balazs Gibizer <balazs.gibizer@est.tech>

Change-Id: Ib387822ae20e2e68489680ff4cfeab20d0cf57bf

[{'created': '2019-06-20 07:45:45.000000000', 'message': "Add capability of adding additional network API extensions

Currently, devstack has NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS var to define
the network API extensions. NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS is defaulted
to 'all' for master and hard coded list of extensions per release.
Zuul jobs of network extensions (for example neutron-fwaas) need
add the some extra extensions in the default list. To do so, they
need to duplicate all the defaults extensions and then add the extra
extensions. Much difficult situation is when defaults extensions list
vary from release to release so they have to keep updating the
NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS per release.

This commit defines a new var ADDITIONAL_NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS which
will take extra extensions and append into the default list. This way
Zuul jobs do not need to duplicate the default extensions.

Change-Id: I7270c9b9e047a851970439522c0356c9089a5b74

commit_message:
Add capability of adding additional network API extensions

Currently, devstack has NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS var to define
the network API extensions. NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS is defaulted
to 'all' for master and hard coded list of extensions per release.
Zuul jobs of network extensions (for example neutron-fwaas) need
add the some extra extensions in the default list. To do so, they
need to duplicate all the defaults extensions and then add the extra
extensions. Much difficult situation is when defaults extensions list
vary from release to release so they have to keep updating the
NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS per release.

This commit defines a new var ADDITIONAL_NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS which
will take extra extensions and append into the default list. This way
Zuul jobs do not need to duplicate the default extensions.

Change-Id: I7270c9b9e047a851970439522c0356c9089a5b74

commit_message:
Add capability of adding additional network API extensions

Currently, devstack has NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS var to define
the network API extensions. NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS is defaulted
to 'all' for master and hard coded list of extensions per release.
Zuul jobs of network extensions (for example neutron-fwaas) need
add the some extra extensions in the default list. To do so, they
need to duplicate all the defaults extensions and then add the extra
extensions. Much difficult situation is when defaults extensions list
vary from release to release so they have to keep updating the
NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS per release.

This commit defines a new var ADDITIONAL_NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS which
will take extra extensions and append into the default list. This way
Zuul jobs do not need to duplicate the default extensions.

Change-Id: I7270c9b9e047a851970439522c0356c9089a5b74
(cherry picked from commit 52c2886f7ede0e47f53b65fd1fd30f7d6ca7c086)

commit_message:
Remove plumgrid support

This change removes all plumgrid templates and options from the code base.
Sadly the company "plumgrid" no longer exists, and because of that, there's
no need to carry this deployment code.

Change-Id: I9767602f6930516b577baf9b2f0feb71e4bf4fdf
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Use tempest_cloud_name in featureset_override

since tripleo now have os_cloud clouds.yaml support for
multinode, standalone and undercloude deployment. tempest and
tobiko now uses os_cloud name for deployment. In order to re-use
the same we can pass it through featureset_override instead of
hardcoding in playbook.

Change-Id: If1112c77664aa0a699bf9778c40a9f20a4651b2d
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

class Rbd(Image):

    SUPPORTS_CLONE = True

    def __init__(self, instance=None, disk_name=None, path=None):
        if not CONF.libvirt.images_rbd_pool:
            raise RuntimeError(_('You should specify'
                                 ' images_rbd_pool'
                                 ' flag to use rbd images.'))

        if path:
            try:
                self.rbd_name = path.split('/')[1]
            except IndexError:
                raise exception.InvalidDevicePath(path=path)
        else:
            self.rbd_name = '%s_%s' % (instance.uuid, disk_name)

        self.pool = CONF.libvirt.images_rbd_pool          ---->the dest pool is config images_rbd_pool
        self.rbd_user = CONF.libvirt.rbd_user
        self.ceph_conf = CONF.libvirt.images_rbd_ceph_conf

        path = 'rbd:%s/%s' % (self.pool, self.rbd_name)
        if self.rbd_user:
            path += ':id=' + self.rbd_user
        if self.ceph_conf:
            path += ':conf=' + self.ceph_conf

        super(Rbd, self).__init__(path, "block", "rbd", is_block_dev=False)

        self.driver = rbd_utils.RBDDriver(
            pool=self.pool,                             ----> RBDDriver's self.pool should same with self.pool
            ceph_conf=self.ceph_conf,
            rbd_user=self.rbd_user)

        self.discard_mode = CONF.libvirt.hw_disk_discard

    .......    
    def clone(self, context, image_id_or_uri):
    .......

        for location in locations:
            if self.driver.is_cloneable(location, image_meta):
                LOG.debug('Selected location: %(loc)s', {'loc': location})
                return self.driver.clone(location,
                                         self.rbd_name,
                                         dest_pool=self.pool)


class RBDDriver(object):

    def __init__(self, pool, ceph_conf, rbd_user):
        self.pool = pool
        # NOTE(angdraug): rados.Rados fails to connect if ceph_conf is None:
        # https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/1787
        self.ceph_conf = ceph_conf or ''
        self.rbd_user = rbd_user or None
        if rbd is None:
            raise RuntimeError(_('rbd python libraries not found'))

    def __exit__(self, type_, value, traceback):
        self.driver._disconnect_from_rados(self.cluster, self.ioctx)

    @property
    def features(self):
        features = self.cluster.conf_get('rbd_default_features')
        if ((features is None) or (int(features) == 0)):
            features = rbd.RBD_FEATURE_LAYERING
        return int(features)

storage/rbd_utils.py

class RBDDriver(object):

    def __init__(self, pool, ceph_conf, rbd_user):
        self.pool = pool
        # NOTE(angdraug): rados.Rados fails to connect if ceph_conf is None:
        # https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/1787
        self.ceph_conf = ceph_conf or ''
        self.rbd_user = rbd_user or None
        if rbd is None:
            raise RuntimeError(_('rbd python libraries not found'))

    def _connect_to_rados(self, pool=None):
        client = rados.Rados(rados_id=self.rbd_user,
                                  conffile=self.ceph_conf)
        try:
            client.connect()
            pool_to_open = pool or self.pool                              -----> the pool is same witg self.pool                  
            # NOTE(luogangyi): open_ioctx >= 10.1.0 could handle unicode
            # arguments perfectly as part of Python 3 support.
            # Therefore, when we turn to Python 3, it's safe to remove
            # str() conversion.
            ioctx = client.open_ioctx(str(pool_to_open))
            return client, ioctx
        except rados.Error:
            # shutdown cannot raise an exception
            client.shutdown()
            raise

commit_message:
Fix error log output information parameters.

Log files always output a log like this
"Clone pool_name/img_name to none/img_name_disk".
According to the log dest pool is none, but it's not actually.
It is easy to debug with this parameter.

Change-Id: I0b2e3ca91967f86946e231f813f69da7d0cbfe32

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-04 16:19:56.000000000', 'message': 'Make Ussuri the future series

If we make Ussuri the future release, the htaccess will be generated
with redirections for it. When we decide that Train is maintained and
not developed, we should move Ussuri to development. And add 'Vancouver'
or something when we know the next series name to immediately generate
the new redirection.

Alternatively, we could change the code to generate the redirections
at all times. If the code is idempotent, we would never have an
issue of "forgotten" state of a series, and could bypass it.

Change-Id: I69008ebd330a90ae42166d55e5c06b694fc2d042
'}]
commit_message:
Make Ussuri the future series

If we make Ussuri the future release, the htaccess will be generated
with redirections for it. When we decide that Train is maintained and
not developed, we should move Ussuri to development. And add 'Vancouver'
or something when we know the next series name to immediately generate
the new redirection.

Alternatively, we could change the code to generate the redirections
at all times. If the code is idempotent, we would never have an
issue of "forgotten" state of a series, and could bypass it.

Change-Id: I69008ebd330a90ae42166d55e5c06b694fc2d042

commit_message:
Check path alive before get scsi wwn

In FC environment, when disconnect volume,
if the first path in the loop is failed,
it will lead get scsi wwn to failure.
So I think we need to add path validity check
before get scsi wwn

Change-Id: I9d3a9dac13dcd585330e7b891c61b2626e5aabec
Closes-Bug: 1831621
(cherry picked from commit 3b8d5b7886b9a45df6b666ef594f4a337914856d)

commit_message:
PDF documentation build

- doc/source/readme.rst is introduced to render both HTML and PDF
  versions properly. The latex builder used to build PDF recognizes
  the document structure based on toctree directives, so a hidden
  toctree for readme is added to index.rst.
- doc/requiremens.txt is introduced to split the documentation
  dependencies following the community convention.
- Along with the previous, python modules only in doc/requirements.txt
  are dropped from lower-constraints.txt as we are not using
  lower-constraints for documentation build.

Change-Id: I8e58cca91506f72b868dec151e070e0f8a69ded4
Story: 2006099
Task: 35126

commit_message:
Restore console proxy deployment info to cells v2 layout doc

This information was mistakenly removed when references to the
nova-consoleauth service were removed from the docs in change
Ie96e18ea7762b93b4116b35d7ebcfcbe53c55527.

Closes-Bug: #1846401

Change-Id: I08fa4650d190114775993e8094efbf46b984dfdc

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-23 14:24:22.000000000', 'message': "Fix evacuation when host dies uncleanly

If a host crashes and ovn-controller doesn't clean up the
Port_Binding chassis column, the Logical_Switch_Port is never set
to DOWN, so we do not detect the up->down transition and update the
port status with the driver. This patch watches for Port_Binding
chassis column changes and if the port is up goes ahead and updates
the driver.

Change-Id: I8a5e6ad2e98b79a140977ce003609ed5b21e3499
Closes-Bug: #1840876
